title: How to Draw and Paint a Poinsettia

steps.title: Use good watercolor paper that will withstand the drawing and later the painting process.
steps.content: Use good watercolor paper that will withstand the drawing and later the painting process. Hold a piece of 9x12 inch paper (or larger) in either orientation.

steps.title: Begin by doing research online and in stores.
steps.content: Begin by doing research online and in stores. Displays are commonplace during the year's end to mark Thanksgiving and Christmas. Study the leaf shape and the cluster of "berries" at the center, which actually contain the true flowers of the plant.

steps.title: Make a light circle as a guide for how far the petals should extend.
steps.content: Make a light circle as a guide for how far the petals should extend.

steps.title: Divide the circle into four sections with light lines.
steps.content: Divide the circle into four sections with light lines. Sketch four leaves, radiating from the center. These are called "modified leaves" or "bracts", and will be the red-colored leaves that are at their brightest in December.

steps.title: Draw a series of tiny circles at the center of the page.
steps.content: Draw a series of tiny circles at the center of the page. These represent the small yellow flowers that form the center of the plant.

steps.title: Work between each leaf and add four more.
steps.content: Work between each leaf and add four more. These will be slightly covered by the original four leaves.

steps.title: Go around again and add another layer of leaves.
steps.content: Go around again and add another layer of leaves. You will only see the tips of these since they are hidden behind others.

steps.title: Color the poinsettia using watercolors, colored pencils or markers.
steps.content: Color the poinsettia using watercolors, colored pencils or markers. While poinsettias come in pink and white varieties, keep this one an example of the pure red variety. It is most common and exemplifies the flower.

steps.title: Color the center flowers yellow and green.
steps.content: Color the center flowers yellow and green. Give each one a tiny stem.

steps.title: Create the green leaves.
steps.content: Create the green leaves. They are shaped exactly like the earlier red leaves but they are green. At the outside border or edge that the pointed petals make, sketch another few petals.

steps.title: Color these leaves green.
steps.content: Color these leaves green. Add a vein pattern to the interior of the leaves.

steps.title: Continue drawing poinsettia.
steps.content: Continue drawing poinsettia. Add three more blossoms to form a bouquet.

steps.title: Check to be sure that each blossom has its own character.
steps.content: Check to be sure that each blossom has its own character.

steps.title: Designate a center of interest.
steps.content: Designate a center of interest. Have a main center blossom just off the middle of the page be the eye-catching center of interest. Accent it by making it more detailed, brighter and more appealing.

steps.title: Fill in around the blossoms with leaves.
steps.content: Fill in around the blossoms with leaves.

steps.title: Create the container, vase, or basket.
steps.content: Create the container, vase, or basket. Draw lightly the various shapes you desire. For a basket, add a curved handle.

steps.title: Pick pure red and green watercolor pigments.
steps.content: Pick pure red and green watercolor pigments. Or, if using colored pencils or markers, use the brightest, clearest shades of red and green. Test them on a scrap of paper.

steps.title: Aim for variety of pigment on each leaf, whether red or green.
steps.content: Aim for variety of pigment on each leaf, whether red or green. This slight change in pressure or density of the color mixture will give the artwork interest.

steps.title: Paint or draw the basket.
steps.content: Paint or draw the basket. Texture is the key. Use brown media such as watercolor on a small pointed brush, or markers to define the basket and handle.

steps.title: Create depth or roundness to the scene.
steps.content: Create depth or roundness to the scene. Dilute the colors as the object recedes. Make lighter and less intense flowers and leaves.

steps.title: Suggest a solid ground for the arrangement to stand on.
steps.content: Suggest a solid ground for the arrangement to stand on. Just a quick pass with light brown is enough. However, if you wish, create a tablecloth, wood surface, etc. It's your decision.

steps.title: Put clusters of red "berries" (the true flowers of the plant) in a few places.
steps.content: Put clusters of red "berries" (the true flowers of the plant) in a few places. This not only fills space but adds interest because the berries are darker and appear hard, giving another visual texture to the arrangement.

steps.title: Incorporate very diluted color for white poinsettias.
steps.content: Incorporate very diluted color for white poinsettias. Use almost plain water and do a quick wash that is barely pink over the blossoms (the white leaves surrounding the center).
